text:
Ciao, and welcome
to 'This is My Architecture'.
I am with Daniel from Pirelli today.

-So thank you.
-Thank you for having me.

And can you please tell us
a little bit more about Pirelli?

Yes, of course. Well, Pirelli
is a 150 year old company.

We are one of the key players
in the tire manufacturing industry.

We are actually the exclusive providers
of the Formula One tires.

And this is because we focus
on high-value products,

especially for the premium and prestige sector
of the car industry.
That's great.

So, I see you are a data engineer,
and we have a data platform here.

So can you please start introducing
your architecture, please?
Yes, of course. Well, as you mentioned,

this architecture represents
our data platform
in which we are ingesting data

from more than 15 factories
all around the world.

Each one of these factories
represent at least six source systems,

which the whole thing amounts
to a total of 4,000 data streams
coming into the cloud.
Okay, so that's a huge amount of data

that you ingest and collect
inside your data platform.

And what kind of data
do you collect today?

Well, it's mainly related
to our production systems

in our factories.
Most of it is relational data.

We do have some non-structured
and documental data.

As you mentioned,
this is a lot of data.

So we mainly rely on big data frameworks
to process all this.
The whole thing starts by the factory

sending us the data to our Kafka clusters
in a real-time fashion.

And then we have this data
being consumed by EMR clusters.

Okay, so the big data platform,
the big data layers are leveraged on EMR.

And what kind of transformation
and processing do you do in this step?

Well, actually, here, we do have
a two-layer set of EMR clusters.

The very first layer,
it holds Flink consumers
that send this data right to S3,
and also to Aurora, everything in real-time.

Then the second layer
is a set of Hudi jobs

that are taking data
from EMR, back to EMR.

And then this whole thing
is written again to S3

and exposed to Redshift
via Spectrum.

So you have, let's say,
a very heterogeneous data lake

at the end with different data sources
for different data as well.

And why have you built it like that?
So what was your purpose?
Well, Pirelli from a couple of years now

has engaged
in digital transformation stream.

And one of the key factors there
is the implementation

of a big data platform
in the cloud,

which is going to represent
a centralized source

for the company data
for all of our users

so that they can implement
the multiple use cases they need.

So itâ€™s the centralized access
as well for all of your users?

And what kind of users, what kind of
audience do you have for this data?

Well, we have a bunch of different users
wanting to leverage different use cases.

On one hand, we have
our factory developers

which implement real-time applications,
mainly querying Aurora databases.

We also have the data scientists
implementing machine learning models
and training them directly on S3 data.
We also have our data analysts,

which are building business
intelligence reports,

directly reading from Redshift or S3
based on the workload that they're using.
And finally, we have our external systems

querying this whole set
of data sources via APIs.
API, okay.

So you mentioned you have been
working on this over the last few years.

So I think you have processed
and transferred a huge amount of data.

If you can estimate
this amount of data and tell us?

Yeah, well, the last time I checked,
we were having 30 terabytes of data.

And we expect this to continue to grow
as the data ingestion process goes on.

And this whole thing has generated
over 500 applications,

distributed across business
intelligence reports,

applications, and our artificial
intelligence systems.

Yeah, great.
So yes, it's a very huge amount of data.

So if you would like
to share any challenges

you may have faced when you
were building this very articulated,
let's say, data platform?
Yeah, well, for me, as a data engineer,

the biggest challenge
was to interact with the business

with the end users and understand
what were their needs,

and tell them which of these data sources
they could use to better fit their needs.

Also, working with
our infrastructure team,

a big challenge
was to automate and monitor

this very complex data platform
to ensure data quality and consistency.

Thank you, thank you for sharing
this great architecture today

and for sharing the challenges
you have faced as well.

And again, thank you
for being here today.
Thank you for the invitation.

And thank you for watching
'This is My Architecture'.
Ciao.
